frame.frame: A woman's value is based on her breast size.
rationale: By asserting that appearance is a woman’s only value, it enforces oppressive, narrow beauty standards.
By centering ridicule on unmet appearance norms, it reinforces oppressive and unattainable standards of beauty.
By emphasizing a body type for its sexual appeal, this frame sexualizes women, viewing their bodies primarily as tools for arousal.
By emphasizing physical appearance as a woman's primary value, the frame treats women as sexual objects, viewing them in terms of their sexual characteristics (Sexualization).
By implying that any woman who fails to meet narrow beauty ideals has no value, the meme enforces unrealistic beauty standards.
By implying that only certain physical traits confer worth, it enforces oppressive and unattainable beauty ideals, reflecting unrealistic beauty standards.
By prescribing appearance as the measure of value, it upholds patriarchal norms that women must conform to beauty standards to be deemed worthy of love or respect.
By prioritizing physical attractiveness above all else, the frame objectifies women and dismisses their individuality and other attributes.
By suggesting that appearance is the only value women have, it enforces oppressive and often unattainable ideals of beauty (Unrealistic beauty standards).
By tying a woman’s worth exclusively to her sexual attractiveness, it treats women as objects defined by appearance, dehumanizing them.
It also evokes conditional respect, implying that a woman’s worth and the respect she receives in a relationship depend entirely on her adherence to these appearance norms.
It also invites judgment and ridicule based purely on appearance, treating women who deviate as unworthy (appearance-based discrimination).
It imposes oppressive and often unattainable ideals of physical appearance on women by suggesting they must meet certain beauty standards to be valued, reflecting unrealistic beauty standards.
It perpetuates oppressive and unattainable ideals by suggesting a woman’s value depends on how her appearance stacks up against peers.
It reduces women to an arbitrary physical trait, promoting an unattainable beauty ideal.
It reinforces oppressive beauty norms by asserting that only conformity to specific appearance standards grants a woman worth.
It reinforces the harmful notion that women must constantly conform to external beauty ideals to be respected or accepted.
It suggests that even efforts to change one’s appearance through plastic surgery fall short of these standards, thereby devaluing women who seek aesthetic modifications.
It uses a ‘meat for men’ metaphor to reduce women’s bodies to consumable objects for male pleasure, illustrating sexual innuendo.
The frame enforces an oppressive and unattainable ideal of physical appearance by suggesting that women's attractiveness depends solely on conforming to narrow traditional beauty norms.
The frame enforces narrow and oppressive ideals of physical appearance by elevating women’s curves as the primary determinant of their worth, reflecting unrealistic beauty standards.
The frame enforces oppressive and often unattainable ideals of physical appearance imposed on women by patriarchal society.
The frame enforces oppressive, narrow ideals of beauty by implying that only certain appearances confer worth, reflecting unrealistic beauty standards.
The frame enforces oppressive, unattainable ideals by implying women’s worth hinges on meeting narrow body-type criteria, reflecting unrealistic beauty standards.
The frame evokes sexual entitlement by suggesting women must maintain a sexualized appearance to retain value, reinforcing the idea that their bodies are owed to others.
The frame evokes unrealistic beauty standards by tying a woman’s worth exclusively to her looks and sexual appeal, enforcing narrow and oppressive ideals.
The frame imposes narrow and oppressive ideals of attractiveness by suggesting that a woman's value and sexual competence hinge entirely on her looks, thereby enforcing unattainable beauty norms.
The frame imposes oppressive and unattainable ideals by asserting that a woman's value hinges entirely on her looks.
The frame imposes unrealistic beauty standards by suggesting that only women who meet narrow ideals of attractiveness deserve value or respect.
The frame objectifies women by reducing their worth entirely to sexual appeal, ignoring their full personhood.
The frame prescribes unequal treatment by deeming women who fall outside narrow appearance norms as unworthy of dating, amounting to appearance-based discrimination.
The frame reduces a woman's entire value to her looks, treating her as an object defined by appearance rather than a full person.
The frame reduces a woman's entire value to how she looks, upholding oppressive and unattainable ideals of female appearance.
The frame reduces a woman's value to external validation of her appearance, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable beauty ideals that define a woman's worth by how attractive she is perceived.
The frame reduces a woman’s worth solely to her physical attractiveness, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable beauty ideals imposed on women.
The frame reduces women to mere bodies by defining their value solely through looks, which is objectification.
The frame reduces women to their appearance, reinforcing oppressive and often unattainable beauty ideals imposed on women (Unrealistic beauty standards).
The frame reduces women to their looks and sexual appeal, treating them as objects for visual and sexual consumption (Sexualization).
The frame reduces women to their sexual appeal and entertainment value, emphasizing their physical attributes as the sole basis of their worth, reflecting sexualization.
The frame reduces women’s value to their looks, imposing an oppressive and often unattainable ideal of physical appearance.
The frame reduces women’s worth to their physical appearance by suggesting that being called “beautiful” is their main priority, reinforcing oppressive and narrow beauty ideals.
The frame sexualizes women by defining their worth solely in terms of sexual appeal, reducing them to objects for visual or physical gratification.
The frame suggests that a woman's value depends solely on her appearance, reinforcing unrealistic beauty ideals and devaluing women who do not conform to them.
The frame upholds narrow and oppressive norms by suggesting that failure to meet specific beauty criteria makes a woman less desirable, reinforcing unrealistic beauty standards.
The meme reduces women's value to their physical traits, treating them as objects whose worth depends on looks, which is objectification.
The meme reduces women’s value solely to their appearance, implying that any deviation from idealized beauty invalidates their worth, which enforces unrealistic beauty standards.
The problem of appearance-based discrimination arises as the frame implies that women who do not meet certain beauty criteria lack value, inviting judgment and exclusion based on looks.
The problem of appearance-based discrimination arises as the frame reduces a woman's worth to her looks, ignoring her individuality, talents, and achievements.
The problem of appearance-based judgment arises as the meme critiques a woman’s aging and praises the use of Botox to erase signs of age, enforcing strict standards for women’s looks.
The problem of derogatory labeling arises because the meme’s use of the term “Butterface” insults and demeans the woman’s face, reducing her to a negative, contemptuous label.
The problem of dismissiveness arises as this frame denies respect and validity to women based solely on failing to comply with arbitrary beauty norms.
The problem of enforced gender norms is evoked as the frame demands women conform to traditional roles and obedience, reinforcing restrictive expectations imposed by patriarchal society.
The problem of fat shaming arises as the frame devalues and stigmatizes women who do not meet this slim ideal by implying that they lack beauty or worth.
The problem of fat shaming arises as the meme mocks individuals for having belly fat, implying that larger body sizes are undesirable and warrant ridicule.
The problem of fat shaming is evoked as the frame labels bodies that don’t conform to these slim, toned standards as shameful, mocking and demeaning women based on their body size.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame equates a woman’s worth with her physical appearance, reducing her identity to how well she conforms to external aesthetic criteria.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame reduces a woman's identity and value solely to her body and looks, treating her as an object rather than a full person.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame reduces a woman's value solely to her physical appearance, depriving her of individual worth beyond looks.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame reduces a woman’s entire value to her physical appearance, treating her as an object defined solely by her looks.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame reduces women to a narrow focus on their physical attributes, particularly cleavage, treating them as objects valued only for appearance.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame reduces women to a single physical attribute—buttock size—instead of recognizing their full humanity.
The problem of objectification arises as the frame reduces women to their looks, treating them as objects valued only for appearance.
The problem of objectification arises as the meme reduces women to their physical appearance, suggesting their worth depends solely on how they look.
The problem of objectification arises because the frame treats women as objects whose sole value is their physical attractiveness.
The problem of objectification is evoked as the frame reduces a woman’s value to her looks and sexual appeal, stripping her of individuality and broader human qualities.
The problem of objectification is evoked as the frame reduces women to their bodies and sexual appeal, denying their full humanity and individuality.
The problem of objectification underpins unrealistic beauty standards by reducing a woman’s worth to her physical appearance and efforts to appear younger.
The problem of reductionism arises as the frame dismisses a woman’s personality and individuality if she does not meet narrow standards of physical attractiveness.
The problem of reductionism arises as the frame reduces women to a single characteristic—their body shape or exercise habit—ignoring their full individuality and diverse attributes.
The problem of reductionism arises because it collapses a woman’s multifaceted identity into a single dimension—how attractive she is and how much attention she commands.
The problem of reductionism is evoked as the meme oversimplifies women's worth and identity into a single physical trait—being 'not fat.'
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme mocks a woman’s natural, unstyled appearance by comparing her to an ugly, wet cat, belittling her looks.
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme mocks the woman’s appearance by sarcastically comparing her to Beyoncé, using humor to belittle her looks.
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme mocks the woman’s original appearance by contrasting an unflattering photo with a glamorous one, undermining her dignity.
The problem of sexual innuendo arises because the frame uses suggestive emphasis on breasts to reduce and commodify women’s bodies as sources of sexual gratification.
The problem of sexual innuendo is evoked because the meme highlights a specific body part (the butt) as the defining feature of a ‘perfect girl,’ sexualizing and objectifying her.
The problem of sexualization arises as the frame reduces women to their sexual appeal by focusing on the sexual allure of their buttocks, treating a body part as their defining value.
The problem of sexualization arises as the frame treats women's bodies as objects whose value depends on novelty, reducing their worth to physical appeal.
The problem of sexualization emerges because the frame treats a sexual body part as the primary measure of a woman’s value.
The problem of sexualization is evoked as the frame treats a woman's body—specifically her sexual characteristics—as the primary basis for her worth, objectifying her.

The problem of transactional relationships is evoked as it frames women’s value in terms of the services they provide—domestic or sexual—treating relationships as economic exchanges rather than partnerships.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame asserts that only women who meet narrow beauty ideals have value, marginalizing all others.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame demands constant change in women's appearance to maintain attractiveness, enforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces a narrow, oppressive ideal that equates slimness with attractiveness and curviness, which is often unattainable and excludes diverse body types.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces an oppressive ideal that women must achieve a specific butt shape through squats to be considered attractive or valuable.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces narrow and oppressive ideals of physical appearance, implying that meeting those standards is the only way a woman can be valued.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces narrow and superficial criteria for a woman's value, pressuring women to conform to oppressive appearance ideals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces narrow, idealized female body types tied to specific workouts, implying that only those shapes are acceptable or valuable.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces oppressive ideals that a woman’s value depends entirely on meeting narrow expectations of attractiveness.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces the oppressive ideal that women must look like celebrities to be considered attractive or worthy of attention.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies a woman’s value is solely determined by her appearance, enforcing oppressive beauty ideals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies that a woman's worth depends on meeting an idealized physical standard, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies that a woman’s value depends solely on meeting oppressive, unattainable ideals of beauty.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies that women must continually maintain a certain level of grooming and attractiveness, enforcing oppressive and often unattainable ideals of physical appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies that women’s natural, unpolished appearance is unacceptable, enforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of physical beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies women must meet certain physical ideals to have worth, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable norms.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame imposes an oppressive ideal that women must have large breasts to be deemed attractive, enforcing narrow and unattainable physical criteria.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame imposes contradictory ideals—praising one trait (large breasts) while mocking another (flat buttocks)—thereby demanding unattainable body norms from women.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame mandates adherence to certain appearance criteria before granting women the basic right to personal preferences.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame prescribes that women must adhere to certain appearance norms to be considered attractive or worthy.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame reduces a woman’s value to narrow, often unattainable ideals of appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame reduces a woman’s worth to her physical attributes, enforcing oppressive ideals of appearance.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame reduces women's worth to their physical appearance, implying that women's value is contingent on meeting certain beauty norms and disregards their individuality and other qualities.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame reduces women’s worth to meeting narrow physical ideals, enforcing an oppressive and unattainable standard of beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame suggests a woman’s worth is based solely on her body attractiveness, imposing narrow and oppressive ideals of physical appearance.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame upholds restrictive and oppressive norms that dictate how women must look, justifying negative judgment and labeling of those who do not conform.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme enforces the idea that women must conform to particular standards of attractiveness to be valued.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme evaluates the woman's value solely on her physical attributes, ignoring her individuality and reinforcing oppressive appearance ideals.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies a woman’s worth is determined only by her looks and simplistic personality labels, enforcing oppressive and narrow ideals of female attractiveness.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that a woman's value hinges on meeting oppressive and often unattainable ideals of body shape and attractiveness.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that an ideal partner must conform to narrow physical attractiveness criteria, dismissing and ridiculing those who do not.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that women must alter their bodies to meet narrow and oppressive ideals, reducing their worth to conformity with these unattainable physical norms.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme imposes narrow and oppressive ideals of appearance, suggesting women must meet certain body criteria to earn social acceptance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme legitimizes unequal treatment of women who do not conform to idealized physical attributes, reinforcing harmful beauty norms.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reduces a woman's value to narrow ideals of attractiveness and labels being overweight as inherently negative, enforcing oppressive and unattainable norms for women's bodies.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reduces a woman's worth solely to her breast size, enforcing a narrow and oppressive ideal that devalues other attributes and perpetuates harmful body expectations.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reduces a woman’s worth to her appearance, implying that only those who meet narrow beauty ideals have value.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reduces the woman’s worth to her physical appearance, reinforcing the notion that women must meet narrow aesthetic ideals to be valued.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reduces women's value to their breast size, promoting oppressive and unattainable ideals of female appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reduces women’s worth to their looks, enforcing oppressive and often unattainable ideals of appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme suggests that only slim bodies are acceptable or desirable, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of appearance for women.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the text and image imply that society's expectations for female bodies are becoming increasingly unattainable and exaggerated.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as this frame enforces narrow, oppressive expectations for women’s appearance and assigns worth accordingly.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as this frame imposes a narrow and unattainable ideal of physical appearance on women, suggesting that their value depends on meeting this specific body requirement.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises because the frame enforces a narrow ideal that a woman's value is tied to the size of her breasts, imposing oppressive appearance norms.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises because the frame ties a woman’s worth to her looks, enforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame asserts that a woman’s worth depends solely on meeting narrow ideals of attractiveness and desirability.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame demands that women maintain an idealized, youthful, and sexualized appearance to be considered valuable.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame enforces oppressive and unattainable ideals of female appearance by focusing on exaggerated physical attributes rather than recognizing women as complete individuals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame limits desirability to a very narrow set of physical traits, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of female beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame reduces a woman’s worth to her physical traits, implying that she must meet specific appearance criteria to be valued.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame reduces women's worth entirely to their looks, demanding adherence to often unattainable beauty norms and dismissing all other qualities or achievements.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame reduces women's worth to their appearance, enforcing narrow and oppressive ideals of physical attractiveness.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame reduces women’s worth solely to their physical appearance, reinforcing oppressive and narrow ideals of beauty.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame shames women for failing to meet arbitrary attractiveness norms by branding them 'lazy,' enforcing the idea that women must constantly conform to oppressive appearance ideals.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame upholds an oppressive and often unattainable ideal of physical appearance for women, suggesting that only slim, toned bodies are worth aspiring to.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the meme enforces an oppressive, narrow ideal that women's attractiveness hinges solely on not being fat.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked by promoting an unattainable and pseudoscientific link between a woman’s body shape and her offspring’s intelligence.
This frame dismisses all other qualities and capabilities of women, insisting that their value hinges on meeting specific appearance standards.
This frame enforces a narrow, oppressive expectation about women’s bodies by prescribing small body size as the criterion for desirability.
This frame enforces the idea that women must meet or exceed arbitrary physical benchmarks set by others, mirroring the meme’s body‐comparison.
This frame enforces unrealistic beauty standards by implying appearance is the primary measure of a woman’s worth.
This frame evokes unrealistic beauty standards by insisting that women uphold an ever-present, idealized look, which is oppressive and unattainable.
This frame evokes unrealistic beauty standards by suggesting that any woman who deviates from a narrow physical ideal (e.g., chest size) deserves to be mocked.

This frame objectifies women by treating them as mere objects whose value lies in looks alone.

This frame reduces women’s worth to their looks, enforcing oppressive and unattainable beauty ideals.

level_1_values.rationale: This broad value emphasizes concern for the welfare of all and opposes evaluating individuals on superficial or self-enhancing grounds such as breast size.

level_2_values.rationale: Focuses on equality and justice for everyone, directly challenging the idea of assigning value to women based on physical attributes.
Encourages acceptance of diverse appearances and identities, opposing narrow, appearance-based beauty standards.
Promotes unbiased, rational assessment of people’s worth, countering subjective, appearance-based judgments.

level_3_values.rationale: Undermines any hierarchy based on body measurements by affirming that all individuals deserve equal respect and opportunity regardless of appearance.
Insists on fair treatment and evaluation of women for their character and abilities, not their breasts.
Opposes narrow beauty norms by valuing a wide range of female forms and personal attributes.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Encourages mature understanding that worth is not tied to conforming to arbitrary physical standards.
Calls for rational, evidence-based judgments of women’s value—focusing on skills, ideas, and contributions rather than appearance.

frame.frame: Women should dress in revealing clothing to be considered valuable or attractive.
rationale: The problem of reductionism is evoked as the frame oversimplifies women’s identities by reducing them to narrow stereotypes—fashion-obsessed and disinterested in empowerment—thereby dismissing their full range of aspirations and capabilities.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame imposes an oppressive ideal that women must adhere to strict beauty norms at all times, devaluing their natural appearance and autonomy.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that women’s worth depends on displaying their bodies, enforcing narrow and oppressive norms of appearance.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme imposes an oppressive and unattainable sexualized ideal on female nurses, reducing their professional value to their physical appearance.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme portrays female champions’ status as contingent on sexualized body shapes, dismissing their abilities and accomplishments and reinforcing narrow beauty ideals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the meme insists that women’s value lies solely in their looks and fashion, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of appearance.
This frame enforces narrow, idealized ideals of how women must look, pressuring them into conservative dress codes and upholding oppressive beauty norms.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame restricts women’s autonomy over their clothing and self-expression, whereas Openness to Change values personal freedom, creativity, and the ability to choose one’s own path.
The frame promotes self-enhancement through external validation, but Self-Transcendence emphasizes caring for others, equality, and justice, directly opposing objectification.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame denies women the right to decide how to dress by imposing a single standard of attractiveness, whereas Self-direction (action) defends freedom of action, independence, and choosing one’s own goals.
The frame enforces patriarchal norms on what women should wear, limiting their freedom of thought. Self-direction (thought) supports freedom of thought and personal ideas against external pressure.
The frame creates unequal value based solely on appearance, violating principles of equality and justice that Universalism (concern) upholds for all individuals.
By demanding revealing clothing, the frame rejects diverse expressions. Universalism (tolerance) fosters broadminded acceptance of different choices and lifestyles.
The frame is based on biased, aesthetic judgments, whereas Universalism (objectivity) advocates for unbiased, evidence-based views that respect individuals beyond appearance.
The frame urges women to modify themselves to meet external standards. The humility in Self-Transcendence, especially self-acceptance, values accepting one’s life and body as they are.

level_3_values.rationale: Counters the frame by affirming that women should independently choose their attire rather than conforming to imposed norms.
Opposes the frame’s prescription by emphasizing women’s right to self-determination in how they present themselves.
Rejects the idea that women’s worth depends on revealing clothing, supporting their ability to set personal goals beyond appearance.
Challenges the frame’s ideological pressure by promoting mental autonomy and the right to form individual perspectives.
Directly contradicts the frame by insisting that all people, regardless of clothing, deserve equal respect and worth.
Undermines the unfair beauty standard by promoting fairness and non-discrimination based on appearance.
Opposes narrow beauty norms by encouraging acceptance of diverse styles, bodies, and self-expressions.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Encourages respecting individuals’ choices about their bodies and attire, rather than judging them by revealingness.
Counters subjective beauty standards by promoting unbiased, evidence-based assessment of people’s worth.
Rejects irrational beauty prescriptions by valuing coherent reasoning over arbitrary demands for revealing clothing.
Challenges the frame by fostering self-acceptance and resisting pressure to meet unattainable beauty norms.

frame.frame: Women should look perfect in all photos.
rationale: By advertising a quick fix to achieve the ideal ‘summer ass,’ the meme reinforces oppressive, unattainable physical ideals imposed on women.

By implying that women who do not alter their appearance through plastic surgery will lack value or future success, the frame humiliates and mocks their natural looks, invoking the problem of ridicule.
By suggesting that women are only attractive if they fit certain physical norms, it perpetuates unrealistic beauty standards.
It also reduces women’s identities to a checklist of appearance and behavior tailored to male desires, stripping away individuality, which reflects the reductionism problem.
It normalizes policing women’s bodies by implying they must remove natural body hair and endure discomfort solely to maintain an appearance deemed acceptable.
It normalizes the oppressive belief that a woman’s value is contingent on meeting arbitrary attractiveness criteria.
It pressures women to conform to superficial criteria that disregard their personal worth beyond looks.
The frame employs ridicule by telling women they ought to feel shame for their bare appearance, publicly humiliating them for not conforming to makeup-driven norms.
The frame enforces the idea that a woman’s worth depends on meeting oppressive and often unattainable beauty ideals, reflecting the problem of unrealistic beauty standards.
The frame imposes oppressive and unattainable ideals of physical appearance on women, reducing their worth to meeting those standards (unrealistic beauty standards).
The frame perpetuates unrealistic beauty standards by suggesting that women's natural looks are unacceptable without cosmetic enhancement.
The frame promotes unrealistic beauty standards by implying a uniform, unattainable ideal that all women are expected to meet.
The frame suggests that women’s bodies must be controlled and punished for non-conformity, enforcing external regulation of female appearance (policing women’s bodies).
The meme perpetuates oppressive, unattainable ideals of physical appearance by portraying only certain body types as acceptable, thereby deeming non-conforming women as inferior.
The meme urges women to alter their bodies (e.g., waxing, taping) to adhere to narrow beauty norms, reflecting unrealistic and restrictive standards.
The problem of ageism arises as the meme equates a lack of makeup with being old, stigmatizing aging and using it as a basis for ridicule.
The problem of appearance-based discrimination arises as it suggests women are only worthy of respect or value if they meet narrow attractiveness criteria.
The problem of objectification arises as the meme reduces women to inanimate, artificial objects—plastic dolls—stripping them of individuality and humanity.
The problem of objectification is evoked as it reduces a woman's worth to her physical appearance and her willingness to conform to those norms through surgery.
The problem of objectification is evoked as the frame reduces women to mere objects whose worth depends only on their appearance and sexual function.
The problem of possessiveness is evoked by prohibiting her from having male friends, reflecting controlling behavior over her social relationships.
The problem of ridicule arises as the frame mocks women who wear makeup by suggesting they are deceptive and publicly humiliating them based on their looks.
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme mocks and belittles women’s unfiltered looks for humor, shaming them for not meeting fabricated beauty norms.
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme mocks women’s bare‐faced appearance by portraying it as inferior, thereby demeaning and belittling them.
The problem of sexual entitlement arises as the meme suggests a woman must always prioritize and fulfill a man's sexual desires, regardless of his attention or engagement elsewhere.
The problem of sexual entitlement is evoked by demanding that a woman must “give head” as a prerequisite for any chance of being with him, implying her sexual services are owed to him.
The problem of sexual innuendo is evoked as the meme uses a double entendre comparing women to a ‘wet and curvy’ racing track, reducing them to sexualized physical attributes for humor.

The problem of transactional relationships is evoked by reducing the relationship to a set of material and sexual exchanges—having a job, cooking, cleaning, and providing sexual favors—rather than mutual respect or emotional connection.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame implies that a woman's natural appearance is undesirable, enforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame imposes narrow, oppressive ideals of appearance on women, pressuring them to meet unattainable criteria.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame imposes oppressive and often unattainable ideals of physical appearance on women.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame prescribes a narrow, unattainable ideal of appearance that all women must meet, marginalizing those who do not.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame promotes women feeling inferior based on appearance, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of female beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the image and text promote a narrow and often unattainable ideal, implying that a woman's value depends solely on her looks.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme endorses extreme plastic surgery as the desirable norm, reinforcing oppressive societal pressures on women to alter their bodies to meet an artificial ideal.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme enforces oppressive and unattainable ideals of physical appearance that women are expected to fulfill.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that women must appear flawless in every photo, imposing oppressive and unattainable ideals of appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that women must wear makeup to be acceptable, enforcing an unattainable norm for natural beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that women should look a certain way—ideally enhanced by filters—thereby demeaning and invalidating their natural appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme implies that women’s natural, makeup-free appearance is unacceptable and unattractive, enforcing oppressive ideals of beauty.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme imposes an impossible expectation for women to always appear attractive in public, valuing them solely for their ability to meet societal standards of beauty.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme promotes an unattainable, synthetic ideal of appearance, pressuring women to conform to an extreme and artificial standard.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme promotes the idea that a woman’s natural appearance is unacceptable and that only surgical alteration can make her beautiful.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme promotes the idea that only through plastic surgery and Photoshop can women achieve acceptable attractiveness, reinforcing harmful, unattainable beauty norms.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme sets an unattainable and narrow criterion for a "perfect woman," pressuring women to meet an impractical ideal of constant sexual availability.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the text implies that only women who meet a certain physical standard are valuable or desirable, enforcing an oppressive, unattainable ideal.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as this frame imposes an oppressive ideal that women’s natural appearance is inadequate without makeup, reinforcing unattainable beauty norms.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises because the frame imposes impossible and superficial criteria—such as exaggerated physical traits—for women to be deemed worthy.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame demands that women fit narrow, idealized physical stereotypes in order to be considered valuable.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the statement implies that a woman's unaltered appearance is insufficient, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals about how women must look.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the statement prescribes cosmetic procedures to meet certain beauty norms, reinforcing oppressive appearance ideals.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked by requiring that she be “skinny thicc ass big tits,” imposing narrow and unattainable ideals of physical appearance on women.
This frame enforces rigid and oppressive beauty ideals, pressuring women to meet specific appearance criteria to earn social validation.
This frame enforces the oppressive ideal that women’s worth is tied to meeting unattainable beauty norms, requiring substantial investment of time and money in their looks.
This frame imposes oppressive and unattainable ideals of physical appearance on women, reinforcing the problem of unrealistic beauty standards.
This frame imposes oppressive and unattainable ideals on women’s physical appearance, reflecting the problem of unrealistic beauty standards.
This frame imposes oppressive, narrow physical ideals on women, enforcing standards that most cannot meet, reflecting the unrealistic beauty standards problem.
This frame reinforces unrealistic beauty standards by mandating that women must constantly work on their looks to gain social acceptance.

level_1_values.rationale: Opposes rigid and oppressive beauty demands by valuing autonomy, innovation in self-expression, and flexibility in standards of appearance.

level_2_values.rationale: Emphasizes freedom of mind and creativity, enabling women to define beauty and self-image on their own terms rather than conforming to patriarchal standards.
Promotes women’s freedom to make choices about how they present themselves in photos—without pressure to meet unrealistic ideals.
Encourages seeking pleasure and well-being, pushing back against constant self-scrutiny and perfectionism imposed by the frame.

level_3_values.rationale: Encourages women to think independently and reject externally imposed beauty norms, opposing the idea that they must conform to perfection in every photo.
Supports the right of women to set personal priorities (comfort, authenticity) instead of chasing unrealistic appearance standards.
Affirms women’s autonomy in self-presentation and self-worth, countering the notion that they need external approval for their looks.
Prioritizes enjoyment and self-care over self-criticism and relentless striving for flawless appearance in photos.

frame.frame: Women's bodies are meant to be subject to men's approval and judgment.
rationale: The problem of objectification arises as the frame treats women as objects for male evaluation rather than autonomous individuals.
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme invites judgment of a woman’s body, belittling her based on appearance.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame reinforces that women’s bodies must conform to men’s subjective standards of attractiveness.

This frame imposes oppressive and unattainable beauty ideals by suggesting that women’s gym attendance should focus on achieving a certain body type to satisfy others’ expectations, reinforcing unrealistic beauty standards.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame denies women autonomy over their own bodies and choices, conflicting with the value of creativity, independence, and self-determination emphasized by Openness to Change.
The frame enforces inequality and devalues women’s welfare, opposing the altruistic, universal concern for equal respect and justice embodied by Self-Transcendence.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame subjugates women’s bodily autonomy to male approval, contradicting the value of women determining their own actions and having control over their bodies.
By insisting women conform to men’s judgments, the frame infringes on women’s freedom to form their own beliefs and values about their bodies.
The frame creates an unequal power dynamic and discriminates against women, opposing the universalist goal of equal rights and fairness for all individuals.
The frame enforces narrow beauty norms and intolerance of diverse bodies, conflicting with the value of accepting and understanding differences among people.

level_3_values.rationale: Woman’s independence over her body is denied by male judgment, so promoting independence directly challenges the frame.
The frame restricts women’s ability to act freely regarding their bodies; valuing freedom of action opposes this restriction.
By subjecting women’s bodies to public male scrutiny, the frame violates privacy; upholding privacy counters this intrusion.
This frame pressures women to internalize male standards, whereas freedom of thought supports women forming their own self-image without external control.
The frame enforces gendered double standards and unequal treatment; valuing equality directly contradicts this oppression.
The frame is unfairly biased against women; promoting justice demands fair treatment without gender-based judgment.
Rigid male-defined beauty norms are narrow and exclusive; valuing broadmindedness encourages acceptance of diverse body types and self-definitions.

frame.frame: Modern women should be regarded as less respectable and more sexualized than women in the past.
rationale: The problem of age-related sexualization is evoked as the meme contrasts a historical photograph with a modern, sexualized image, implying that women of different generations must conform to increasingly inappropriate sexual expectations.
The problem of enforced gender norms arises as the frame reinforces traditional expectations that women belong in domestic roles and must conform to patriarchal ideals.
The problem of reductionism arises because the frame oversimplifies women’s identities by reducing their worth to domestic tasks and appearance alone.

The problem of sexual innuendo arises because the frame implies that performing household duties in high heels or sexualized clothing is titillating, treating the woman’s body as an object of sexual amusement.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame imposes oppressive expectations that women must look attractive—even during chores—to be valued.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the meme suggests a decline in moral standards tied to women’s appearance over time, enforcing oppressive and unattainable ideals of attractiveness.

level_1_values.rationale: The misogynistic frame enforces rigid, traditional roles for women and denies their autonomy and self‐expression, directly opposing the value of embracing change, exploration, and individual freedom.

By reducing modern women to sexual objects and denying them respect, the frame undermines compassion, solidarity, and concern for all human beings, contradicting the value of caring for others’ welfare and striving for equality.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame prescribes how women should be perceived, restricting their freedom of beliefs and ideas, whereas Self-direction (thought) values the right to form one’s own thoughts and perspectives.
By dictating women’s social image and behavior according to past norms, the frame denies women the ability to choose their own goals and act independently, in direct conflict with this value.

Labeling modern women as less respectable ignores the principle of equal worth and justice for all, whereas Universalism (concern) demands fairness, protection of the vulnerable, and equal opportunities.
The frame enforces narrow judgments and stereotypes about women, rejecting diversity of identities and experiences, while Universalism (tolerance) calls for broadminded acceptance of differences.

level_3_values.rationale: The frame discourages questioning or reinterpreting traditional gender roles, whereas valuing curiosity encourages exploring new perspectives on women’s identities.
By prescribing a fixed, derogatory view of modern women, the frame denies them intellectual autonomy, in contrast with the right to think freely.
The misogynistic frame treats women as passive objects of judgment, contradicting the value that individuals should shape their own lives without external imposition.
The frame imposes an outdated standard of respectability and sexualization, undermining women’s ability to set and pursue their own life goals.
By enforcing restrictive norms about how women should be seen, the frame limits their social agency, contradicting the freedom to act as they choose.
The frame’s core message of devaluing modern women directly opposes the principle that all people deserve equal respect and opportunity.
Assigning lower respect and undue sexualization to modern women is unjust and discriminatory, clashing with the value of fairness and unbiased treatment.
The frame relies on stereotypes and a narrow, past‐oriented view of women, whereas broadmindedness embraces diverse experiences and identities.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: The misogynistic stereotype refuses to recognize modern women’s dignity, in conflict with the value of mature acceptance of people even when they differ from traditional norms.

frame.frame: Women are deceptive about their appearance on social media.
rationale: By framing women’s social media posts as deliberate deception, the meme reinforces the pressure on women to conform to these artificial standards.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme denigrates women who use cosmetic procedures as 'fake', reinforcing the harmful notion that their value depends solely on 'natural' beauty and that surgical enhancement is inauthentic.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the meme suggests that women present curated, idealized images online that set unattainable expectations for real-life appearance.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame limits women’s autonomy and enforces rigid beauty norms; valuing openness to change counters these restrictive standards and supports self-direction.
The frame degrades women’s dignity and denies equality; valuing self-transcendence promotes universal respect, justice, and the welfare of all genders.

level_2_values.rationale: Counters the policing of women’s images by affirming their right to independent thinking and self-expression.
Promotes women’s autonomy in choosing how to present themselves and opposes patriarchal constraints on appearance.
Encourages equal treatment and opposes demeaning stereotypes that portray women as dishonest about their looks.
Fosters acceptance of diverse appearances and challenges narrow, unrealistic beauty ideals imposed on women.

level_3_values.rationale: Opposes the demand that women conform to narrow beauty standards by protecting their right to self-defined identity.
Affirms women’s agency over their bodies and online presence, rejecting patriarchal policing of their appearance.
Recognizes women’s right to control their own images and personal data without judgment or accusation of deceit.
Emphasizes women’s capacity to make autonomous choices about their appearance free from external scrutiny.
Affirms that women deserve the same respect and freedom of self-expression as men, challenging sexist hypocrisy.
Encourages acceptance of all body types and presentations, undermining oppressive beauty norms.
Demands fair treatment of women and rejects the false stereotype that they are inherently deceptive about their looks.

frame.frame: Women become worthless as they age.
rationale: It enforces unrealistic beauty standards by suggesting only youth and attractiveness grant women value.
The frame devalues women based on their age, implying that aging strips them of worth, which is a clear example of ageism.
The problem of ageism arises as the frame devalues women based on their advancing age and fading appearance.
The problem of ridicule arises as the meme mocks and belittles the woman’s appearance when she is pictured as a girlfriend versus an ex.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame equates a woman’s worth solely with her physical attractiveness, implying that loss of beauty nullifies her value.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme enforces oppressive and unattainable ideals by suggesting a woman’s attractiveness is only valid under certain conditions.

level_1_values.rationale: This frame denies women autonomy and growth by equating aging with worthlessness; valuing openness to change emphasizes personal development and self-determination regardless of age.
The frame assigns value based solely on external beauty, ignoring the common good and equality; self-transcendence counters this by emphasizing care, justice, and concern for all individuals.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame restricts women’s ability to define their own worth and life goals as they age; self-direction (action) affirms women’s right to pursue independent choices at any stage of life.

By suggesting women lose value with age, the frame suppresses freedom of thought about self-worth; self-direction (thought) supports women’s intellectual autonomy and internal value beyond appearance.
The frame devalues women’s capacity for empathy and meaningful relationships as they age; benevolence (caring) highlights the enduring importance of compassion and social bonds regardless of age.
The frame upholds a narrow standard that discriminates against older women; universalism (concern) promotes equality and justice, affirming that all women deserve equal respect and opportunities.
By dismissing women’s worth with age, the frame reflects intolerance toward diverse life experiences; universalism (tolerance) encourages broadminded acceptance of different ages and appearances.

level_3_values.rationale: Counters the frame’s implication that women lose agency as they age by affirming women’s right to self-reliance and decision-making at every age.
Challenges the idea that aging women should conform to external beauty norms by supporting women’s pursuit of personal ambitions beyond appearance.
Opposes the frame’s stereotype by endorsing women’s intellectual autonomy to define their own worth independent of societal beauty ideals.
Rejects the notion that aging diminishes women’s social or personal efficacy by recognizing their ongoing ability to act and contribute.
Affirms that women’s capacity for compassion and connection remains valuable throughout life, opposing the frame’s devaluation of older women.
Highlights the continued worth of aging women through acts of care and support, contradicting the frame’s message of worthlessness.
Directly rejects the age-based discrimination in the frame by asserting that women of all ages deserve equal respect and opportunities.
Counters the injustice of dismissing women’s value when they age, emphasizing fair treatment and non-discrimination based on appearance or age.
Opposes the narrow beauty standard behind the frame by promoting openness to diverse expressions of aging and appearance.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Encourages appreciation of individuals beyond superficial traits, directly challenging the frame’s devaluation of aging women.

frame.frame: Female video game characters are meant to be sexualized and objectified.
rationale: It promotes unattainable and exaggerated body proportions for women, reflecting the problem of unrealistic beauty standards.
The frame reduces female characters to objects of visual pleasure by emphasizing their sexual attributes, evoking the problem of sexualization.
The problem of sexual innuendo arises as the frame encourages exaggerating body curves to evoke sexual connotations, reducing the character to a sexual object.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame promotes unattainable, exaggerated body ideals that pressure female characters to conform to narrow and oppressive physical norms.

level_1_values.rationale: The misogynistic frame treats women as objects, disregarding their dignity and shared humanity; Self-Transcendence emphasizes caring for others and promoting equality, directly opposing this dehumanization.

level_2_values.rationale: This value calls for equal opportunities and protection of all people regardless of gender, countering objectification and unrealistic beauty standards.
Promoting acceptance and understanding of different appearances and identities undermines narrow, sexualized stereotypes imposed on female characters.

level_3_values.rationale: Insisting that women in games be treated with the same respect and opportunity as men rejects objectification and one-dimensional sexualization.
Upholding fairness in representation challenges the unfair imposition of oppressive and unattainable beauty standards on female characters.
Encouraging openness to diverse character designs and narratives opposes the narrow trope of sexualized, objectified female figures.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Valuing acceptance of different body types and roles for women in gaming counters the rigid beauty ideals central to this misogynistic frame.

frame.frame: Real women are inferior and less desirable compared to the exaggerated, idealized anime versions of women.
rationale: The frame enforces an ideal based on exaggerated, sexualized proportions of anime characters, promoting an oppressive and unattainable beauty standard for Japanese women.
The problem of sexualization arises as the frame privileges exaggerated sexual characteristics (large breasts) as the measure of desirability, objectifying women.
The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame promotes an unattainable, cartoonish body ideal that real women cannot match.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame devalues real women by elevating unrealistic, idealized images, thus disregarding the importance of concern for others, equality, and justice that underlie self-transcendence.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame denies real women’s worth and disregards the universal value of equality and fairness for all individuals, essential to universalism (concern).
By favoring idealized anime characters and rejecting real women, the frame shows narrow-mindedness; universalism (tolerance) promotes openness and acceptance of diverse forms of beauty and identity.
The frame objectifies and devalues actual women, undermining compassion and empathy; benevolence (caring) emphasizes loving and caring for the welfare of others.

level_3_values.rationale: Asserting equal respect and opportunities directly contradicts the idea that real women are inferior or less desirable.
Promoting fair and impartial treatment of individuals opposes the unfair devaluation of women based on unrealistic beauty standards.
Encouraging acceptance of varied appearances and preferences counters the narrow, idealized beauty norms imposed by the frame.
Fostering empathy, affection, and care toward real women challenges the objectification and rejection implied by the frame.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Promoting maturity and understanding toward differences contradicts the frame’s dismissal of real women in favor of fantasy images.

frame.frame: Women should focus on making their mouths more attractive to draw attention.
rationale: By urging women to alter their natural appearance to meet certain aesthetic criteria, the frame enforces oppressive and unattainable beauty standards.
The frame reduces women to their physical features by implying their value lies in how attractive their mouths are, reflecting objectification.
The problem of objectification is evoked as the frame treats women as tools or objects for visual appeal, ignoring their full personhood.
The problem of sexualization is evoked as the frame reduces women to sexual objects whose bodies are instruments for gaining attention.

The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the frame implies that physical attractiveness is the primary means for women to be valued, promoting oppressive and unattainable appearance ideals.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame restricts women to narrow beauty standards, disregarding the value of innovation, autonomy, and self-expression that Openness to Change champions.
By objectifying women and promoting unrealistic beauty ideals, the frame undermines concern for others, justice, and equality central to Self-Transcendence.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame dictates how women should look, ignoring their right to think freely and develop their own ideas about self-worth and appearance.
By prescribing that women focus on appearance to gain attention, the frame denies women autonomy in choosing their own goals and actions.
The frame’s objectification of women contradicts the pursuit of equality, justice, and respect for all people that Universalism (concern) upholds.
Enforcing a single standard of attractiveness shows closed-mindedness toward diverse expressions of beauty, opposing the value of broadminded acceptance.
Objectifying women for their physical features conflicts with the caring and compassionate treatment of individuals that Benevolence (caring) encourages.

level_3_values.rationale: This frame suppresses women’s freedom to think for themselves about their bodies and worth, instead imposing external beauty norms.
It discourages exploration of identities and self-definition beyond appearance, counter to the value of curiosity and discovery.
It pressures women to conform to external standards rather than empowering them to chart their own course and define their own goals.
By insisting women focus on their looks to gain attention, the frame limits their ability to act freely in pursuit of varied aspirations.
Promoting the objectification of women’s bodies diminishes their equal status and rights with men, violating the principle of equality.
Reducing women to physical attributes is unfair and discriminatory, undermining the impartial treatment and protection of the vulnerable.
The frame enforces a singular beauty ideal, whereas broadmindedness calls for acceptance of diverse appearances and self-expressions.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Encouraging women to pursue one narrow standard of attractiveness contradicts mature acceptance of different identities and choices.
Objectification conflicts with valuing compassionate, respectful relationships that prioritize people’s intrinsic worth.
Instead of supporting women’s self-esteem and varied talents, the frame directs them to seek approval through appearance, opposing genuine help and empowerment.

frame.frame: Women are supposed to define their identity and worth by how they groom their pubic hair.
rationale: The problem of unrealistic beauty standards is evoked as the meme pressures women to conform to narrow, appearance-based norms about pubic hair grooming.
The meme mocks changing expectations over time, reinforcing that women must meet specific grooming ideals to be valued.

level_1_values.rationale: This frame enforces rigid beauty norms and conformity. Openness to Change contradicts it by valuing individual autonomy, creativity, and freedom from societal grooming rules.

This frame treats women’s bodies as objects for public appraisal rather than valuing all people equally. Self-Transcendence contradicts it through concern for equality, justice, and respect for individual differences.

level_2_values.rationale: This frame demands that women internalize externally imposed grooming rules. Self-direction (thought) contradicts it by emphasizing freedom of thought and the right to form one’s own standards.
The frame dictates women’s grooming behaviors. Self-direction (action) opposes it by championing independence in making personal decisions about one’s own body.

This frame discriminates by gender and perpetuates unequal standards. Universalism (concern) contradicts it by promoting equality, fairness, and protection of the vulnerable against such oppressive norms.
The frame stigmatizes any deviation from a narrow grooming norm. Universalism (tolerance) counters this by encouraging acceptance and understanding of diverse personal grooming choices.

level_3_values.rationale: The frame imposes fixed beliefs about women’s bodies; advocating freedom of thought undermines this by supporting independent reasoning about personal appearance.
The frame demands compliance with societal dictates on grooming; valuing independence affirms that women can make their own bodily choices.
The frame restricts women’s actions regarding their own bodies; championing freedom of action empowers them to decide their own grooming practices.
The frame creates a double standard on women’s appearance; prioritizing equality rejects unequal, gendered expectations and supports equal treatment in beauty norms.
The frame enforces a narrow definition of acceptable grooming; broadmindedness encourages openness to diverse practices and personal definitions of beauty.

frame.frame: Supermodels should maintain their attractiveness by eating very little.
rationale: The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as this frame implies that staying attractive requires extreme dieting or self-starvation, promoting unhealthy and unattainable body standards for women.

level_1_values.rationale: Rejecting unrealistic beauty standards and embracing autonomy and critical thinking contradicts the frame's enforced conformity and self-discipline.
Valuing equality and acceptance of diverse bodies counters the frame's narrow, oppressive ideals.

level_2_values.rationale: Emphasizing freedom of thought empowers individuals to challenge imposed beauty norms rather than internalize them.
Supporting autonomy in personal choices opposes the frame’s insistence on restricting eating behaviors for social gain.
Promoting equal respect for all body types undermines the frame's hierarchical valuation of appearance.
Encouraging acceptance of diverse appearances contradicts the narrow standard of attractiveness enforced by the frame.

level_3_values.rationale: Encouraging critical reflection on societal pressures opposes the self-discipline required to maintain unrealistic thinness.
Upholding individual autonomy in life choices contradicts the pressure to conform to strict dieting for social validation.
Asserting that all people deserve respect regardless of body shape directly challenges the frame’s hierarchy of attractiveness.
Fostering openness to different body types undermines the frame’s narrow definition of beauty.

frame.frame: Women who are both attractive and intelligent are meant to be unattainable and superior to men.
rationale: The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the meme reinforces the stereotype that women with both attractiveness and intelligence are out of reach for most men, creating oppressive and unattainable ideals.

level_1_values.rationale: The frame’s assertion of unattainable and superior women denies the equal worth and concerns for all people; self-transcendence emphasizes caring, justice, and equality for everyone, contradicting hierarchical judgments based on appearance or intelligence.
The frame imposes rigid, unrealistic ideals on women, whereas openness to change values personal autonomy, creativity, and the freedom to define oneself beyond external standards.

level_2_values.rationale: By promoting equality and justice for all, universalism (concern) rejects the notion that any group (including attractive and intelligent women) should be placed above others.
This value encourages acceptance of diverse appearances and abilities, opposing the frame’s narrow and exclusionary ideals.
Emphasizing compassion and support for others counters the frame’s competitive, superiority-based messaging that devalues solidarity among women and men.
Humility discourages elevating any individual or group as inherently superior, directly challenging the frame’s portrayal of certain women as ‘unattainable’.
Valuing freedom of thought empowers women to reject imposed beauty standards and define their own worth.
Valuing freedom of action supports women’s autonomy to live authentically rather than being constrained by patriarchal ideals.

level_3_values.rationale: Counters the frame by affirming that no individual should be deemed inherently superior based on looks or intellect.
Promotes impartiality and fairness, rejecting discriminatory standards that elevate some women above men.
Encourages openness to different expressions of beauty and intelligence, undermining narrow ideals.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Fosters mature appreciation of diverse individuals without ranking them as superior or unattainable.
Emphasizes empathy and connection over competition and hierarchy between genders.
Opposes notions of superiority by valuing modesty and mutual respect.
Enables individuals to question and dismantle oppressive beauty and intelligence standards.
Supports women’s agency to define and pursue their own goals, free from patriarchal constraints.

frame.frame: A woman’s need to work should depend on her attractiveness: unattractive women must work hard, while attractive women need not.
rationale: The frame reduces a woman’s worth and effort to her physical appearance, reinforcing oppressive and unattainable beauty ideals.
It implies that beauty alone justifies reduced effort, echoing unrealistic standards that value women primarily for their looks.

level_1_values.rationale: This frame enforces rigid beauty-based rules that limit women’s autonomy, contradicting the value of encouraging creative thinking and self-determination.
By discriminating based on attractiveness, the frame undermines concern for all individuals’ welfare and equality, opposing the value of universal human dignity.

level_2_values.rationale: The frame denies women the freedom to choose work based on their skills and goals, contradicting the value of independence and self-determined action.
It discriminates among women based on appearance rather than needs or abilities, opposing the value of equal opportunity and social justice for all.
By valuing only certain appearances, the frame rejects acceptance of people who differ from idealized standards, opposing broadminded appreciation of diversity.
The frame relies on biased judgments of attractiveness rather than rational criteria, contradicting the value of forming unbiased and evidence-based opinions.

level_3_values.rationale: Argues that women should decide their careers by personal aspirations and qualifications, not be forced into work based on how they look.
Supports women’s right to plan their lives and careers without being constrained by societal beauty judgments.
Directly opposes the frame’s discrimination, insisting all women have the same rights and opportunities regardless of appearance.
Promotes fairness in evaluating women’s work contributions based on merit rather than physical attractiveness.
Encourages acceptance of all women’s varied looks and abilities, opposing narrow and exclusionary beauty standards.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Calls for understanding and valuing individuals beyond superficial traits, contradicting the frame’s shallow basis.
Advocates for rational arguments about women’s work and capabilities, rather than irrational biases tied to attractiveness.

frame.frame: There are only two acceptable types of female genitalia, creating unrealistic and harmful standards.
rationale: The problem of unrealistic beauty standards arises as the frame enforces a narrow, prescriptive view of women’s bodies, implying that only two genital shapes are acceptable.
The problem of reductionism arises as the frame oversimplifies women’s identities by reducing their worth and diversity to just two categories based on anatomy.

level_1_values.rationale: This frame imposes rigid norms on women’s bodies, denying creativity and autonomy; Openness to Change emphasizes valuing new ideas and diversity, directly opposing these restrictive standards.
The frame discriminates against those who don’t fit imposed beauty ideals; Self-Transcendence promotes equality and concern for all individuals, rejecting harmful hierarchies and prejudice.

level_2_values.rationale: By mandating only two acceptable genital types, the frame stifles independent thought about bodily diversity; Self-direction (thought) champions freedom of thought and individual perspectives.
The frame limits women’s autonomy over their bodies; Self-direction (action) supports personal decision-making and bodily self-determination.
This frame excludes and shames those who differ; Universalism (tolerance) encourages acceptance and understanding of differences, opposing narrow beauty norms.
The frame enforces unequal standards and harms marginalized individuals; Universalism (concern) advocates for equality and justice for all, challenging discriminatory ideals.

level_3_values.rationale: Opposes the frame’s enforcement of a single acceptable standard by encouraging independent reflection on bodily diversity.
Challenges the notion of one proper form by valuing new and diverse perspectives on beauty and anatomy.
Contradicts the demand for compliance with narrow norms by supporting individual autonomy and self-determination.
Rejects external control over personal bodies by affirming the right to make choices about one’s own anatomy.
Opposes the frame’s exclusionary stance by fostering acceptance of all variations without prejudice.

level_3_values.level_3_value: Have the wisdom to accept others
level_3_values.rationale: Counters harmful judgments by encouraging mature acceptance of bodily differences.
Directly challenges discriminatory beauty standards by promoting equal respect regardless of genital appearance.
Defies unfair norms by upholding fairness and protection for those marginalized by narrow beauty ideals.
